title: Ally of President Macron Targeted in French Corruption Probe
text:
PARIS—French prosecutors have opened a probe into the past business activity of the speaker of the National Assembly, muddying efforts by President Emmanuel Macron to clean up politics in the wake of the yellow-vest crisis.

Investigators in the city of Lille are examining whether Richard Ferrand, who ran Mr. Macron’s presidential campaign, abused his role as an executive at Mutuelles de Bretagne in 2011, when the health insurer decided to rent a building from Mr. Ferrand’s girlfriend, the prosecutor’s office said Thursday. Prosecutors questioned Mr. Ferrand until late in the night Wednesday.

Mr. Ferrand is a close aide of Mr. Macron and was among the first lawmakers to join his new political party in 2016.

A previous probe targeting Mr. Ferrand’s time at Mutuelles de Bretagne was dismissed in 2017. The new probe was triggered by a complaint filed by an anticorruption group.

Mr. Ferrand, 57, said he was unalarmed since the plaintiff didn’t bring any new evidence to the case. He added that he was determined to stay in his job.

Mr. Ferrand has always denied wrongdoing.

The fresh probe is a setback for Mr. Macron who has pledged to end nepotism and favoritism in his political ranks following months of at times violent yellow-vest protests. Public anger about the perceived privileges of the country’s elite drove thousands of protesters to weekly protests, bringing the government to its knees.

Government spokeswoman Sibeth Ndiaye said Thursday that Mr. Macron remained confident in Mr. Ferrand.

“Until proven otherwise, he is presumed innocent,” said Ms. Ndiaye. “He’s a loyal, upright man who has had, I believe, an exemplary political career.”

Accusations against Mr. Ferrand surfaced in 2017 after weekly Le Canard enchaîné reported that Mr. Ferrand’s girlfriend won the rental contract from Mutuelles de Bretagne in 2011 when Mr. Ferrand was in charge of the insurer.

Other French media reported Mr. Ferrand continued to work as a consultant for Mutuelles de Bretagne while serving as a lawmaker and participating in parliamentary debates about changes to France’s health-insurance industry.

Weeks later, judges in the city of Brest, where Mutuelles de Bretagne is based, launched an investigation into Mr. Ferrand. He resigned as housing minister but stayed on as lawmaker. Judges dropped the case later that year.

Mr. Ferrand became speaker of the National Assembly in September 2018.

Write to Noemie Bisserbe at noemie.bisserbe@wsj.com
description: French prosecutors have opened a probe into the past business activity of the speaker of the National Assembly, muddying efforts by President Emmanuel Macron to clean up politics in the wake of the yellow-vest crisis.
